item.title: Return type and ; required
item.dc:creator: @supamagier supamagier
item.description:
@supamagier wrote:

If you want to learn to code, you should put a lil more effort into logical thinking…
That you don’t call your operator the same as your class name is a simple beginner mistake, nothing wrong with that. But… for example:

public static void main(String args[]) { new NewOperatorMethod(); }
You use ‘new NewOperatorMethod()’. Do you see anywhere in the class a method (in this case that statement will be wrong too, but that doesn’t matter now) or an operator with the name NewOperatorMethod? Do you have any class in the same folder with this name? If not, you really should consider thinking better, even if you already do the best you can…

Good luck,

Matt.

Read full topic

item.title: Return type and ; required
item.dc:creator: @nueb35 Nueb35
item.description:
@nueb35 wrote:

you have to be copying and pasting. its like no one makes these types of mistakes…

[tt]public class Demo {[/tt]

that means the constructor should also be [tt]Demo[/tt] and not [tt]OperatorMethod[/tt] and ofcourse to initialize this you do [tt]new Demo();[/tt] not [tt]new NewOperatorMethod();[tt] unless there is a class in the class path named “NewOperatorMethod” and you want to initialize that instead

Read full topic

item.title: Return type and ; required
item.dc:creator: @dogzound5 dogzound5@gmail.com
item.description:
@dogzound5 wrote:

I am writing a little practice code with variables and loop statements and it says a return type required and a “;” on my output statements but I already have the semicolons and I was following a guide. Any help on what I did wrong would be great!!

[code]public class Demo {

    public OperatorMethod() {
    
            int a, b, c, d, e;
            
            int a = 50;
            int b = a;
            int c = 40;
            c = d = e;
            
                    System.out.println("Integer A :" + a);
                    System.out.println("Integer A & B = each other because ::" + a " = " + b);
                    
            int maxCValue = 75;
            int c = 60;
            
            while (c < maxCValue) {
                    System.out.println("C is less than the max value of C which is " + maxCValue);
                    
            }
    }
    
    public static void main(String args[]) {
            new NewOperatorMethod();
    }

}

            [/code]

Read full topic
